cause of action: Copyright Infringement, 17 U.S.C. 1202 Removal of Copyright Management Information

caption: The Intercept Media, Inc. v. OpenAI, Inc.
description: Nonprofit news organization sues generative AI developer and its financial backer, alleging that its news articles have been unlawfully used to train ithe popular AI chatbot ChatGPT.
application ares: Copyright, Generative AI, Intellectual Property, Natural Language Processing
cause of action: Copyright Infringement, 17 U.S.C. 1202 Removal of Copyright Management Information, Digital Millennium Copyright Act

caption: The New York Times Company v. Microsoft
description: The New York Times Company sues Microsoft and OpenAI, alleging that they have committed direct, contributory and vicarious copyright infringement; misappropriation of news items, and trademark dilution through the training and operation of their generative AI services Copilot and ChatGPT.
cause of action: Copyright Infringement, Trademark Dilution, Commercial Misappropriation, 17 U.S.C. 1202 Removal of Copyright Management Information

caption: Thomas v. Wells Fargo & Company
description: Plaintiffs seek damages for Defendants’ -- Wells Fargo-- discriminatory practices in denying their applications to refinance their Wells Fargo mortgage loans in violation of the federal Fair Housing and Fair Lending acts, as well as state consumer protection laws.
cause of action: Civil Rights, Fair Housing Act, Unfair Competition
issues: Lack of Human Review, Lack of Remedy, Programmer Bias, Use of Race

caption: Thomson Reuters Enterprise Centre GmbH v. ROSS Intelligence Inc.
description: Legal publisher and research platform provider sues legal research startup, alleging that it induced another company to copy headnotes and key numbers from its Westlaw online legal research service to train a bot that would return legal materials from natural language queries, giving rise to claims for copyright infringement and tortious interference with contractual relations.

caption: Thornley v. Clearview AI, Inc.
description: Plaintiffs filed class action complaint alleging that plaintiffs’ and class’s biometric identifiers and biometric information were included in defendant’s database in violation of Section 15(c) of the Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act.
cause of action: Biometric Information Privacy Act, Illinois Biometric Information Privacy Act

caption: Toronto Star Newspapers Ltd. v. Open AI Inc.
description: Canadian news organizations sue generative AI developer, claiming that its use of their works to train its models infringed copyright, circumvented technological measures, violated terms of use, and amounted to unjust enrichment.

caption: Twitter, Inc. v. Taamneh
description: On May 18, 2023, the Supreme Court of the United States decided Twitter, Inc. v. Taamneh, No. 21-1496 (Twitter), holding that plaintiffs who were injured in a terrorist attack failed to state a claim against Facebook, Twitter, and Google for “aiding and abetting” an “act of international terrorism” under 18 U.S.C. § 2333(d)(2), the Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act.

caption: Tyndaris v. VWM Limited
description: Suit by Tyndaris for unpaid fees, countersuit by VWM for misrepresentation and breach of contract, first determining if under civil liabilty Tyndaris is responsible as a custodian for the algorithm's mistakes, expected to be landmark case as first UK case to discuss machine learning
cause of action: Article 1465 of the Civil Code of Quebec, Breach of Contract

caption: U.S. v. Levandowski
description: Court entered into a plea agreement for widescale theft of trade secrets. Levandowski worked for Waymo, a Google subsidiary and had downloaded thousands of files on Google's self driving car program. Many of these documents were confidential.

caption: Umeda v. Tesla, Inc.
description: Court dismissed suit by estate of Japanese pedestrian killed by Tesla Autopilot operated by Japanese driver because Japan is an adequate alternative, denying plaintiff's motions for judicial notice of articles about Tesla personnel changes and Tesla's forecasts but granting Plaintiff's motion to include congrsesional hearings about autopilot and an article about the specific accident
cause of action: Design Defects, Failure to Warn, Loss of Consortium, Negligence, Survival Action, Wrongful Death

caption: UMG Recordings, Inc. et al. v. Suno, Inc.
description: Record companies bring lawsuit for copyright infringement against Suno, a generative AI service that allows users to create digital music files based on text prompts, alleging that Suno trained its AI model on copyrighted music libraries without permission.

caption: UMG Recordings, Inc. et al. v. Uncharted Labs, Inc.
description: Record companies bring lawsuit for copyright infringement against Udio, a generative AI service that allows users to create digital music files based on text prompts, alleging that Udio trained its AI model on copyrighted music libraries without permission.

caption: United States v. Curry
description: Court found that there were no exigent circumstances to justify the police seizing a defendant with no suspicious activity near the scene of gunshots because an algorithm indicated the area would be a hot spot for criminal activity, where the concurrence and dissent addressed that predictive policing algorithms have been shown to have questionable effectiveness and clear racial bias.
issues: Human Programming Flaws, Predictive Policing, Unreliability, Use of Race

caption: United States v. Meta Platforms, Inc.
description: On June 27, 2022, the court approved the parties’ settlement agreement and entered a final judgment in United States v. Meta Platforms, Inc., f/k/a Facebook, Inc. (S.D.N.Y.). The complaint, which was filed on June 21, 2022, alleged that Meta’s housing advertising system discriminated against Facebook users based on their race, color, religion, sex, disability, familial status, and national origin, in violation of the Fair Housing Act (FHA). Specifically, the complaint alleged, among other things, that Meta uses algorithms in determining which Facebook users receive housing ads and that those algorithms rely, in part, on characteristics protected under the FHA. Under the settlement, Meta stopped using an advertising tool (known as the “Special Ad Audience” tool) for housing ads and developed a new system, the Variance Reduction System (VRS), to address racial and other disparities caused by its use of personalization algorithms in its ad delivery system for housing ads.
issues: Advertising DIscrimination, Socioeconomics Bias, Targeted Advertising, Use of Race, User of Gender

caption: United States v. RealPage, Inc.
description: The United States and ten States bring an antitrust action against RealPage, Inc. and six rental real estate companies, alleging that RealPage's real estate revenue management software, called AIRM and YieldStar, have enabled landlords to collude and fix rental prices.

caption: United States v. Smith
description: This criminal indictment charges Michael Smith and others with wire fraud and money laundering for having obtained over $10 million in royalties by uploading over 100,000 songs created with artificial intelligence to streaming platforms and then streaming those songs thousands of times using bots.

caption: United States v. Wilson
description: The 9th Circuit found that the defendant's Fourth Amendment rights were violated when Google's algorithm—without opening the email—detected child pornography attached to one of the emails he sent and reported it to law enforcement.
application ares: Constitutional Law, Criminal Justice, Privacy, Search and Seizure

caption: Vacker v. Eleven Labs, Inc.
description: Voice actors and owners of copyright in their narrations sue AI text-to-speech service developer, claiming violations of rights of pubilcity and privacy, misappropriation of likeness, unjust enrichment,circumvention of technical protection measures, and removal of copyright management information
cause of action: Right to Privacy, Unjust Enrichment, Right of Publicity, 17 U.S.C. 1202 Removal of Copyright Management Information, Digital Millennium Copyright Act

caption: Van Pelt v. Cigna Group
description: The action, which was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Connecticut, captioned Van Pelt v. The Cigna Group, et al., Case No. 3:23-cv-01135, alleges that Defendants have implemented sophisticated automated intelligence capabilities to systematically defraud consumers by denying medically necessary claims en mass without appropriate physician review. The action further alleges that Cigna’s automated systems allow its medical directors to automatically deny medically necessary claims without even opening patient medical records. The action further alleges that Cigna’s automated review program reportedly automatically denied without review over 300,000 claims, spending an average of 1.2 seconds on each claim.
cause of action: Breach of Contract, Unfair and Deceptive Trade Practices, Unjust Enrichment
issues: Accountability, Individualized Assessment, Lack of Human Review, Lack of Remedy, Misuse of AI

caption: Velesaca v. Decker
description: Class action filed by non citizens detained in New York challenging the "no release policy," arguing that a change to the assessment algorithm resulted in a lack of ICE bond hearings and solely recommending detention, with preliminary injunction granted to return to individualized assessment due to COVID safety
cause of action: 5th Amendment, Administrative Procedure Act, Immigration and Nationality Act, Preliminary Injunction, Rehabilitation Act, Due Process Clause

caption: Vermont v. Clearview AI, Inc.
description: Vermont Attorney General brought three Vermonst consumer protection claims: unfair and deceptive practices by collection photographs and making misrepresenations about their program and fraudelently acquiring brokered personal information against Cleaview, and it survived a motion to dismiss where Clearview argued 1A, 230, Standing and Venue in M2D

caption: Walters v. OpenAI, L.L.C.
description: Plaintiff sues developer of ChatGPT for defamation, alleging that ChatGPT generated false and defamatory statement about him as having embezzled from an organization called the Second Amendment Foundation. Defendant removes to this federal court.

caption: Walters v. OpenAI, LLC
description: Plaintiff sues developer of ChatGPT for defamation, alleging that ChatGPT generated false and defamatory statement about him as having embezzled from an organization called the Second Amendment Foundation. Defendant removed to federal court.

caption: Waymo LLC v. Uber Technologies, Inc.
description: Waymo sued Uber and Ottomotto for patent infringement and violations of trade secret laws, claiming that its former employee, Levandowski, improperly downloaded documents related to Waymo’s driverless vehicle technology, then left Waymo to found Ottomotto, which Uber subsequently acquired.
cause of action: Defend Trade Secrets Act Of 2016, Unjust Enrichment

caption: Wayne Jones V. Mean LLC, et al.
description: The tech companies Reddit and YouTube are facing a lawsuit filed by the survivors of a racist shooting in Buffalo that alleges the sites' algorithms helped to radicalize the shooter and prepare him for the attack.

caption: WeRide Corp. v. Kun Huang
description: Autonomous vehicle companies won suit against a former employee and his current autonomous vehicle employer for misappropriation of trade secrets, succeeding on likelihood to succeed on the merits when they demonstrated particular files in the code base and demonstrated that the source code was only accessible on-site or using a VPN by employees.

caption: Williams v. City of Detroit
description: Individual sues city for false arrest for alleged theft based on faulty facial recognition technology (settlement in June 2024 included major policy changes to Detroit police use of facial recognition, and presumably payment to individual and his attorneys)
application ares: Criminal Justice, Detention and Release, Facial Recognition
issues: Facial Recognition, Lack of Human Review, Law Enforcement, Socioeconomics Bias, Reliability

caption: Williams-Sonoma, Inc. v. Amazon.com, Inc.
description: Williams-Sonoma sued Amazon for, among other things, copyright infringement stemming from Williams-Sonoma-owned photographs that an Amazon algorithm selected for display on Amazon's website from photographs submitted by third-party vendors. The court denied Amazon's motion to dismiss, holding that there were sufficient allegations that Amazon engaged in "volitional conduct" through its algorithm in selecting the photographs, and that Amazon's algorithm took actions that disqualified it from DMCA section 512(c) safe harbor protection.

caption: Woodruff v. City of Detroit
description: A woman who says she was wrongfully arrested after facial recognition technology misidentified her as a suspect in a carjacking and robbery — while she was eight months pregnant — is suing the police department that detained her.
application ares: Criminal Justice, Detention and Release, Facial Recognition
issues: Facial Recognition, Law Enforcement, Socioeconomics Bias, Unreliability, Use of Race, Reliability

caption: Young v. NeoCortext, Inc.
description: Reality show cast member brings putative class action against developer of the "Reface" generative AI photo-editing app, alleging that the unauthorized use of his likeness and those of other California residents in altered images generated by the app and use to advertise the app's capabilites violated their right of publicity.

caption: Zalatel v. Prisma Labs
description: The district court balanced the trademark infringement likelihood of confusion factors, focusing on the functionality of the defendant's machine learning programming that creates a machine redrawn image rather than photo filtering

caption: Zhang v. Baidu.Com, Inc.,
description: A group of New York residents who advocate for increased democracy in China sued Baidu for blocking their materials in the United States. The court found that allowing plaintiffs to sue Baidu for its editorial judgements would violate the First Amendment.

caption: Zhang v. Google LLC
description: A group of visual artists seeks to bring a class action lawsuit against Google LLC and Alphabet Inc., alleging that their training and operation of the text-to-image generative AI system Imagen constitutes direct copyright infringement (by Google) and vicarious copyright infringement (by Alphabet). (Consolidated into In re Google Generative AI Copyright Litigation)

caption: Zynda et al. v. Zimmer et al.
description: Settlement agreement in which Michigan's Unemployment Insurance Agency admits no wrongdoing in its use of MiDAS (Michigan Integrated Data Automated System) that wrongfully accused 40,000 residents of fraud, in exchange for terms of reasonable review and investigation into UIA's procedure and policy, requiring future commnications in plain language and with adequate notice, and providing the claimant with reasons for why they were flagged for fraud and ability to appeal
application ares: Agency, Civil Rights, Fraud, Unemployment Insurance
cause of action: Due Process, Social Security Act, Injunction
issues: Accountability, Lack of Human Review, Lack of Remedy, Notice, Role of Expert Testimony, Miscalculation
